---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

- [x] depends on: #5580 
- [x] depends on: #5734

* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#5734~~

I note that @j-loreaux has self-assigned this so I have just left one minor comment. However this all looks _great_ to me!
Thanks Oliver, I meant to get to this Friday and then got caught up with some personal stuff. I'll have a look today.
bors r+

  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/5896306743/job/15993912517)
I'm so excited for this! It's very nicely done, thanks!
Do you have plans to add the result  that `LocallyConvexSpace ℝ E ↔ BarrelledSpace ℝ E`?

I don't think that's true. Does the docstring make it sound like it would be true?

The usual counterexample is to take the normed space of continuous functions on `[-1, 1]` equipped with the L2 norm (so it's definitely not complete), and consider the sequence of continuous linear forms defined by integrating against an approximate identity with L2 norm equal to one. That sequence of continuous linear maps converges pointwise to the evaluation at 0, yet evaluation at zero is not continuous in L2 norm, which contradicts the Banach Steinhaus theorem.
Sorry this was a total thinko on my part! All is well.

No worries!

I don't think completeness can help here without metrizability (in which case you have a Baire space so this PR covers it), but I don't know any particular counterexample.

right?
```suggestion
  which is equivalent to requiring that `𝓕` is Von Neumann bounded
```
What I mean is that for all `x`, the set of all `𝓕 i x`s is bounded, so I would keep the "pointwise". Do you have a better way to say it?

Oh I guess you're saying that it's equivalent. I think that's true indeed, but I would say that it's a bit too far from the actual statement to be useful (e.g we don't have the equivalence in mathlib right now). What do you think?
Well, actually I just misread this the first time. :laughing: So, let's just ignore it.
This is also called the *Uniform Boundedness Principle* or the *Principle of Uniform Boundedness*. Please include that (only one of these is necessary) in this documentation.

```suggestion
of the theory). Since we can easily prove the normed space version over any
```
I love it when we out-Bourbaki Bourbaki. :smiley:

```suggestion
    refine Seminorm.continuous' (r := n + n) ?_
```

paired with the change above:
```suggestion
```
It would also be nice to mention the term *Uniform Boundedness Principle* here to aid in searching the docs.

A priori it may not be clear to the reader that seminorms form a conditionally complete lattice, so when you say "assumption" here, it's not quite clear what you mean, especially because the `⨆` could be taken as a pi-type supremum (via the `FunLike` coercion). So, perhaps mention that the pointwise supremum of bounded above seminorms is itself seminorm.
I tried to be more explicit, is it better? I could also try to completely hide the lattice of seminorms in the comment.

```suggestion
  toLinearMap := linearMapOfTendsto _ _ h
```
I'm not sure we need this as a separate `def` anymore, and I would advocate against it, but if we are going to have it, perhaps it can be an `abbrev`.

You mean keeping only the general definition right? Or do you mean we shouldn't express this using a def at all?

Assuming the first case, the reason I kept this one separate is because of the extra `WithSeminorms` argument. That's the downside of not using `LocallyConvexSpace`, we can't have the typeclass system take care of the generalization here. One solution would be to have a typeclass saying "there exists a family of seminorms generating the topology" but I don't really want to do that. Otherwise we could just expect the user to provide `norm_withSeminorms 𝕜₂ F`, but that sounds a bit annoying too. Anyway I'll definitely make it an `abbrev`.

Yes, the first case is what I meant. I thought making the use supply `norm_withSeminorms` wasn't too burdensome, but an `abbrev` is also totally fine, I just didn't want two only semi-reducibly equivalent versions.

As for the type class saying "there exists a family of seminorms generating the topology", why do you find this so problematic? Just because it's a `Prop` mix-in and you are worried about blowing up the search space, or because you actually want the data? For what it's worth, this is exactly how I always think of LCTVS in mathematics. But we can probably have this discussion elsewhere.

> I thought making the use supply `norm_withSeminorms` wasn't too burdensome.

It's definitely not a huge burden, but I think it's better if people can just work in normed spaces out of the box since it's such a common place.
